section-block.rac_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.rac_book_summary: We learn about our world through our five senses. In this book, we will learn lots of new words to talk about what we see, hear, taste, smell, and touch.

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65089-1. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses by Jane Brocket. Text and photographs copyright © 2014 by Jane Brocket. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Millbrook Press, a division of Lerner Publishing Group, Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_body-text: Introduce the five senses to children by asking: What foods taste sweet? What things feel soft? What colors are bright? What has a terrible smell? What makes a loud sound?
Have children sing about each of their senses to the tune of “The Mulberry Bush”: This is the way we smell with our nose, smell with our nose, smell with our nose . . . etc.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses by Jane Brocket.
Scout loves informational books because they teach us things. This is an informational book that tells about our five senses.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What do our eyes tell us?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do we see in the picture? What are our five senses? What senses do we use when we’re on a street with a lot of cars?
What do our eyes tell us about? What colors do we see here? Can you find the patterns in these pictures?
What do we notice with our eyes on these pages? Do you see any shapes? Numbers?
What do we use our noses for? Have you ever smelled something stinky? Let’s pretend we just smelled a stinky skunk. Why do people hold their noses when they smell something stinky? (MB)
Which senses do we use when we cut out cookies? When we take a walk outside?
Look at the pictures. What do you see with your eyes? Do you see any words? Numbers? What colors do you see?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What do our eyes tell us?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They help us read words and numbers.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about using the five senses as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do our eyes tell us about colors or smells?
Our eyes tell us about c_____ (colors).
Our eyes tell us about colors.
What patterns can you see in the classroom?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschool children use their senses to explore materials, positions, and motion. They need vocabulary to express their discoveries about nature, motion, weather, energy, and the environment. Encourage scientific language as they participate in class discussions.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Ask and Answer Questions

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Sometimes we need to ask a question if we don’t understand something. We can ask questions to find the answer. When I read today, raise your hand if you have a question about the book. If you know the answer, raise your hand. When we ask and answer questions, we learn or share information.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to use the ask and answer questions Mind Builder as we revisit the book Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses by Jane Brocket.
This book is about the five senses. Clifford enjoys asking questions about things we see, touch, taste, smell, and hear.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the book to notice the ask and answer questions Mind Builder in action.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do we see? Does anyone want to ask what the word steep means? (MB)
How do we know this is a steep street? Have you ever walked up a steep set of stairs? (MB)
What do you think cozy socks are? When something is cozy, it’s very comfortable. Do you have a favorite cozy blanket? Are you cozy in your bed at night? (MB)
Does anyone want to ask what grainy sand is? Are the pebbles grainy or smooth? (MB)
Does anyone want to ask what damp means? When something is damp, it’s a little bit wet. Can anyone figure out what bulbs are? (MB)
Some of these pictures have a nice smell and some have a stinky smell. Can you sort the pictures into nice and stinky smells?

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to use ask and answer questions as they play a game of Riddle Riddle Ree, I See Something You Don’t See. Choose one child to start the game. The child chooses an object in the room and says: Riddle Riddle Ree, I see something you don’t see and it’s _______ (color). Other children guess the object. Whoever guesses correctly gets to be the next leader.
Monitor the play to make sure the objects chosen are the color described and in plain sight.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about using the five senses.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Asking and answering questions are key executive function skills used to learn and share when communicating with others. We practice this skill when we ask who, what, when, why, where, and how questions. We also use it when we ask follow-up questions related to an original question. (Ed.gov/Early Learning/Talk Read Sing)

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children to make connections with pictures in the book.
Invite children to play Simon Says, focusing on the senses. Say: Point to the body part you use to see. Point to what you use to smell. Wiggle what you use to touch, etc.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are reading Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses by Jane Brocket.
Scout the Squirrel loves this book because he enjoys making connections to foods he likes to eat. What connections can you make?
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What words can we use to talk about how foods taste?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What part of our body do we use to taste? Who can show me how you look when you eat something sweet?
Raise your hand if you like sour foods.
What are some sour foods?
Have you ever tasted salty peanuts? Is there a food you eat at home that tastes salty? Do you like salty foods?
Have you ever eaten lettuce leaves? Not all lettuce leaves taste bitter. Most people don’t like things that taste bitter. Let’s make believe we’re taking a drink of something that tastes bitter.
We can taste many flavors. Have you ever eaten cherries? What other fruits are juicy? Have you ever eaten chili peppers? What foods are spicy?
What do you see on this page? Raise your hand if you know what something minty tastes like. Often, foods that have a mint taste or flavor are colored green. Have you ever eaten mint ice cream?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What words can we use to talk about how foods taste?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We can say food is sweet.
We can say food is sour.
We can say food is spicy.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about how different foods taste, inviting children to add end punctuation.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can we say that food is sad or salty?
We can say that food is s_____ (salty).
We can say that food is salty.
Can you name three salty foods?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Introducing children to different words that describe how things taste, smell, look, sound, and feel is a great opportunity to expand their English vocabulary. Children might already know some concepts, like salty, in their home language, and simply need an English label. Concepts, such as bitter, may be new conceptually.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about what they learned this week about our five senses. What are our five senses? What do we use to see, smell, hear, taste, and feel or touch?
Teach children the song “Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes.” Encourage children to touch each body part as they sing.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch! It is a poster that gives us information. We call it an informational poster.
Scout loves to look at informational posters because he likes to learn new things.
Cold, Crunchy, Colorful and See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch! give us facts about our senses. Let’s see if we can find any connections between the two.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Cold, Crunchy, Colorful book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
What can we learn from using our senses?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Five Senses
section.rac_body-text: Invite children to talk about the Big Chart. What senses do we see? What body parts do we use for each sense? Then read the teacher text on the back of the Big Chart, having children act out each section.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are binoculars? Pretend you’re using binoculars. What do we notice with our eyes?
Does rotten garbage smell good or bad? How does scented soap smell? Have you ever smelled freshly baked bread?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show page 20 of Cold, Crunchy, Colorful.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Point to the picture of the ear. What sound does a bell make?
Point to the picture of the mouth. How many sweet foods can you name?
Can you name something that feels soft? Hard? Cozy?

section.rac_body-text: Have children draw a picture of the body part associated with one of their senses and then draw an arrow to what they can see, hear, smell, or feel with that sense.
Provide a writing prompt about one of the five senses and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: The ability to understand the meaning of graphic images is a developmental skill for preschool children. Be prepared to support differing levels of ability to see the purpose and meaning in the arrows, separate circles, and images that illustrate the boy’s senses. This is a valuable skill that will benefit children as they move towards literacy.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to play a game of “Name the Senses.” Point to a body part, and have children tell which sense the body part uses. For example, point to your ear and encourage children to name the sense of hearing. Extend the game by inviting children to act out using each sense that they name.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses by Jane Brocket.
Scout knows that this book is nonfiction. It’s not a story or a narrative. It is an informational text that tells about using our five senses.
This week we read about our senses and what they can do. As I read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What kinds of sounds can we hear?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: What do we use our ears for? What makes a loud sound? Do clanging bells make a loud sound or a soft sound?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why do drivers honk their horn when there is a lot of traffic?
Show me how you would honk your horn!
What are the quiet sounds in these pictures? Can you make a sound like a clock ticking? Would you use a loud voice in school? Can you show me how you would ask a teacher for help? (MB)
What kind of plant is this? What part of the plant is sharp?
Let’s pretend we touched a sharp cactus. Ouch!
What part of our body do we use to taste? Raise your hand if you like foods that taste sweet. Spicy. Salty. Sour.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to Turn and Talk with a partner about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What kinds of sounds can we hear?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write about sounds they can hear and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can we hear horns honking or purring?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: A child’s vocabulary in kindergarten is the biggest predictor of that child’s ability to read on or above grade level by grade 3. Repetition of vocabulary and hearing the word in a variety of contexts are vital to children internalizing words. Keep a list of previously taught vocabulary and find opportunities each day to revisit some of those words.
